First of all, who says that Germany has been practicing anything that an American would recognize as austerity? Second, even if a government reduces spending and/or raises taxes (fiscal consolidation), the contractionary effects can be offset by increasing exports. Unfortunately, this balance of trade surplus is necessarily accompanied by deficits in other countries.

If Germany is the industrious ant and the rest of Europe the slacker grasshopper, it is an ant that makes its living by selling to grasshoppers while not buying from them. When its customers start to find this state of affairs unaffordable, the ant tells them to all sell more and buy less. Of course, the ant doesn't really mean it; it knows it can't be done. Besides, what are your options if your customers can no longer afford to buy from you?

Katie Houston

Based on her description in the article as amazingly talented in many ways and often severely depressed, Mary Kennedy was likely another undiagnosed sufferer of bipolar disease. The alcohol and pills are frequent self-medications by such sufferers.

I am familiar with this disease, as it runs on one side of my family, and my best friend, who was a celebrated author, had the same swings and committed suicide in 1980. It is sometimes called the genius disease, because so many talented writers, artists, actors and professors have it. These people can be more charming than anyone else in the manic stage, then hideout when they are in the depressive phase. It is hereditary and stays in the gene pool because of the charming and talented side of the pattern.

I believe if people who have friends and family members who suffer these swings would look carefully at the person and try to get her/him to get treatment, lots of bipolar people could be saved from the suffering. It is often easier for people to accept and get treatment for a disease that is a brain chemistry imbalance than to be treated like "crazy" people. Testing for this disease should be done before diagnosis of some other problem and lots of time wasted in ineffective treatment.

I send my condolences to all of Mary Kennedy's family and many friends. She clearly will be very missed by a lot of people.

I'm curious.  Has any study been done of completed social science studies that offers an empirical evaluation of how often the confidence level meets that goal?  That is, over a broad range of social science studies, are the predictions of those studies sufficiently accurate in the extrapolated populations the studies were designed to measure?  Or are the disciplines all based on the statistics of significantly small samples and extrapolations are taken for granted?

The use of statistics in behavioral research risks flawed results when the method is applied to groups in which many differing backgrounds, education, and life experience may provide rather differing response to the impulses imposed by daily living. Statistics brings a rather blunt sword to the analysis of data, and the results are blurred in the process. Even the notion of 95% confidence is an approximation that arises from the similarities in system response to an impulse, a stretch when applied to human behavioral analysis. Certainly the questions asked will have bearing on the certainty garnered statistically. One could suppose that if asked whether the people in the group wished to die today the statistical response would pass that confidence test. In most issues the individual responses will contain varying personal identity concerns.

One can select participants for a study, use a variety of questions to select a compatible group, and gain a high confidence in the analysis of response. However, rounding up a group of people off the street will seldom yield such stellar results.

This 95% is an arbitrary number.  It means being wrong 5% of the time, which could be called a large error tolerance.  Anyway, the question is not about one study but about science, which means understanding of process.  There the social sciences are weak.

People are not as different as you postulate. We can predict with a high degree of certainty just how a particular population will react in a given situation.

A study in psychology must have a 95% confidence rate to be considered valid. Or a correlation coefficient of .95 to be considered predictive of behavior. While it is true, there will always be variations, and those that do not fit in the general study, we can make assumptions based on these factors.

These are the kind of studies that make it possible to design an efficient airliner instrument panel for instance. Unlike the hard sciences we rely on statistics to allow us to predict what will happen in a given situation. But that does not invalidate these studies of human behavior. We know we can not predict with 100% certainty how any one individual will react to a given situation, but that is the best method we have so far.

The Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum [PETM] 55 million years ago had a sudden release of methane from methane hydrates at the bottom of the Arctic ocean and methane and CO2 from permafrost. The result was a 9 degree spike in climate temperature. Such a thermal spike now would put a sudden end to agriculture and civilization. We humans would probably go extinct. The amount methane stored in those meltable reservoirs is even larger now than it was before the PETM.
"Six Degrees: Our Future on a Hotter Planet" by Mark Lynas

Dan,

Yes, the globe has been cooling for nearly a decade and a half now. This is acknowledged by even the most ardent of AGW theory's scientific advocates.

Had you read the CRU emails, the emails between and amongst the most ardent scientific advocates of AGW theory, their panicked concern over how to address the problem posed to AGW theory by the "missing heat" would have made their acknowledgment of recent global cooling obvious to you.

This acknowledgment may explain the theoretical name change, from Catastrophic Anthropogenic *Global Warming* to Catastrophic Anthropogenic *Climate Change*.

With the globe's climate changing from moment to moment everywhere on earth, and with a very limited record of previous weather events of note (due to a much more sparsely populated earth, as well as more primitive monitoring and reporting technologies), convincing the general public that a weather event somewhere on earth is "unprecedented" in scope or extent is made much easier.

And convincing the public of a need for vested interest action, rather than gathering truly reliable information about the past, present and future behavior of the globe's climate, appears very much the goal of the governmental, academic and media powers that be.

You’re right Dave, the earth has been much warmer in the past, any climate scientist would tell you that. You need to ask yourself some very important questions though about previous warm periods. First, how much warmer was it, how much higher were sea levels, and what was the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere at that time. These are the kinds of questions climate scientists ask to better understand what’s going on now and how things may change in the future. If it was considerably warmer than today, if sea levels were several meters higher and if C02 levels were higher than pre-industrial levels then I might be a little concerned.

The idea that clouds produced by cosmic rays will be some kind of cosmic saviour for humanity is not based in any sound science. Consider that the cosmic ray theory of cloud production still largely depends on some as yet not very well understood formation of cloud condensation nuclei. Any CCN that cosmic rays might be responsible for would be a small percentage of those already being produced by human activities such as coal burning and the black soot from your tailpipe. Saltby’s idea that C02 rise is not being caused by humans has been thoroughly discredited. Maybe a final question you might ask yourself is if humanity isn’t contributing to C02 rise then where exactly are our emissions going.

JD:

CO2 is just a trace gas like arsenic is just a trace water containment. It doesn't matter what the ratio of CO2 is to oxygen and nitrogen is because they don't block heat effectively like CO2 does. A sheet of paper can block more light than a swimming pool filled with water.

If you're on top of Mt. Everest without an oxygen supply you are going to die even though oxygen is still 22% of the air up there. It is the number of molecules, not the percent that counts. And we have added one trillion tons of CO2 to the atmosphere. That matters. A lot.
